text:
Something else I haven't seen anyone mention that we heavily take into account when gauging time to rank is topical authority.

Business impact and topical authority are the two most important things we consider when deciding which topics to tackle and in what order.

*For Example:*
We’ve built up topical authority around a particular health supplement for an ecommerce client of ours.

Current DR is less than 20. We don’t actively build links—they get approx. 1-2/month, if that.

We decided to tackle a relatively large topic (90K SV) in December with buying intent:

> _best x for y_
> 
Published the article on Dec 30th and began ranking on the first page (6-7) by Jan 4th. Ranking is holding steady so far and many long-tail variants are quickly climbing up page 2.

This has worked to break into different core topics successfully as well — for both B2C and B2B companies.

We developed an algorithm that identifies and prioritizes this for us now—making content planning and projecting results way easier and more reliable than it used to be.

But for everyone else, here’s how to approach it and still get some good results:

Find the topics for which you already have first page (preferably top 3) rankings for. From there, identify closely related topics. Then segment further to find the ones that will provide the most business value currently.

If you take that approach, you can rank for your target topics much more quickly a majority of the time despite your domain authority and often without having to build links. 

If you find a particular topic isn't budging, it’s usually one of the following:

• You fundamentally messed up intent (though, we still often break into page 1 by taking a controversial position to the dominant intent).
• You didn't pick a sufficiently proximal topic.
• Links may be more important for that particular topic. We reserve this one for last so we’re aren't wasting time and budget building links just for the sake of building links.
*Caveat:* You do actually need some content that ranking well before you can begin to benefit from the acceleration this provides. If you don’t have that yet, focus on tackling long-tail terms that are closely related to one another to begin getting some traction first.
